original_theorem:
Suppose that $g$ is continuous at $x_0,$ $g(x_0)$ is an interior point
of $D_f,$ and $f$ is continuous at $g(x_0).$ Then
 $f\circ g$ is continuous at $x_0.$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem continuous_at_comp_of_continuous_at_and_continuous_within_at
    {α β γ : Type*} [TopologicalSpace α] [TopologicalSpace β] [TopologicalSpace γ]
    {g : α → β} {f : β → γ} {x₀ : α} {D_f : Set β}
    (h_g_cont : ContinuousAt g x₀)
    (h_gx0_interior : D_f ∈ 𝓝 (g x₀))
    (h_f_cont_within : ContinuousWithinAt f D_f (g x₀)) :
    ContinuousAt (f ∘ g) x₀ := by
```

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0
open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem continuous_at_comp_of_continuous_at_and_continuous_within_at
    {α β γ : Type*} [TopologicalSpace α] [TopologicalSpace β] [TopologicalSpace γ]
    {g : α → β} {f : β → γ} {x₀ : α} {D_f : Set β}
    (h_g_cont : ContinuousAt g x₀)
    (h_gx0_interior : D_f ∈ 𝓝 (g x₀))
    (h_f_cont_within : ContinuousWithinAt f D_f (g x₀)) :
    ContinuousAt (f ∘ g) x₀ := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• $f$ is a function from a metric space $Y$ to a metric space $Z$ with domain $D_f \subseteq Y$, and $g(x_0)$ is an interior point of $D_f$ [tc_2].
• $f$ is continuous at $g(x_0)$ [tc_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta_1 > 0$ such that for any point $t \in Y$, if $|t - g(x_0)| < \delta_1$, then $t \in D_f$ and $|f(t) - f(g(x_0))| < \epsilon$ [l1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics: have h_f_cont : ContinuousAt f (g x₀) := h_f_cont_within.continuousAt h_gx0_interior

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0
open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem continuous_at_comp_of_continuous_at_and_continuous_within_at
    {α β γ : Type*} [TopologicalSpace α] [TopologicalSpace β] [TopologicalSpace γ]
    {g : α → β} {f : β → γ} {x₀ : α} {D_f : Set β}
    (h_g_cont : ContinuousAt g x₀)
    (h_gx0_interior : D_f ∈ 𝓝 (g x₀))
    (h_f_cont_within : ContinuousWithinAt f D_f (g x₀)) :
    ContinuousAt (f ∘ g) x₀ := by
  have h_f_cont : ContinuousAt f (g x₀) := h_f_cont_within.continuousAt h_gx0_interior
  sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• $g$ is a function from a metric space $X$ to a metric space $Y$, and is continuous at $x_0 \in X$ [tc_1].
• For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta_1 > 0$ such that for any point $t \in Y$ with $|t - g(x_0)| < \delta_1$, we have $t \in D_f$ and $|f(t) - f(g(x_0))| < \epsilon$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For a given $\epsilon > 0$ and its corresponding $\delta_1 > 0$ from [l1], there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that for any point $x \in X$, if $|x - x_0| < \delta$, then $g(x)$ is defined and $|g(x) - g(x_0)| < \delta_1$ [l2].

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0
open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem continuous_at_comp_of_continuous_at_and_continuous_within_at
    {α β γ : Type*} [TopologicalSpace α] [TopologicalSpace β] [TopologicalSpace γ]
    {g : α → β} {f : β → γ} {x₀ : α} {D_f : Set β}
    (h_g_cont : ContinuousAt g x₀)
    (h_gx0_interior : D_f ∈ 𝓝 (g x₀))
    (h_f_cont_within : ContinuousWithinAt f D_f (g x₀)) :
    ContinuousAt (f ∘ g) x₀ := by
  have h_f_cont : ContinuousAt f (g x₀) := h_f_cont_within.continuousAt h_gx0_interior
exact h_f_cont.comp h_g_cont
